ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Take it if you are at all interested in stem cells!
Yes, but it is very much a survey of recent work being done in stem cells. If you are interested in stem cells, definitely take this course.

I wouldn't recommend this course to another student, but it does seem like a better option compared to many of the other graduate courses. Really, the problem is that there are almost no courses for graduate students, and the ones that do exist are strangely (and somewhat pathetically) bad. It might be the lesser of evils, in the sense that at least it doesn't take up too much time and prevent you from being in lab.
I will recommend fellow students who has interest in stem cell or would use stem cell as material in their research for the class.
I would recommend it. It provides a comprehensive overview of the current state of stem cell research.
Yes. One of the advantages of being at yale and listen to lectures from great professors.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: I now know that I will not rotate in a stem cell lab.
My research topic touches on stem cell and would like to use stem cells as material. This class gives great introduction and extensive knowledge on the subject.
It helped me really understand ChIP-seq
